historicalName: Calle del Gran presso Santa Maria Formosa
englishName: Calle del Gran near Saint Mary Formosa
historicalDescription: This area in the Castello sestiere was known for its proximity to the Church of Santa Maria Formosa, one of the oldest churches in Venice, originally built in the 7th century and rebuilt in 1492.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the coppersmiths who had workshops nearby, crafting essential items like pots and pans for Venetian households. This guild was particularly important near Santa Maria Formosa where many artisans worked.

This dock served the jewelers who had shops in the area around Santa Maria Formosa. Venice was famous for its fine jewelry craftsmanship during the Renaissance, and wealthy merchants would commission pieces from these artisans.
Named for its proximity to the Church of Santa Maria Formosa, which houses important Madonna paintings. The dock would have been used by worshippers and clergy arriving by water to the church.

Named after the residents of the Santa Maria Formosa parish who used this landing regularly. Local identity in Venice was strongly tied to one's parish, and this dock would have been a community gathering point.
Named after a decorative column capital or small shrine that once stood nearby. Such architectural elements often served as neighborhood landmarks in Renaissance Venice.

During the Renaissance, barbers also served as surgeons and bloodletters. This dock was named for the barber shops that operated in the vicinity of Calle del Gran, providing essential services to Venetians.
This dock may have been used by wedding processions heading to Santa Maria Formosa. Venetian weddings often involved water processions of decorated gondolas carrying the bride to church.
Venice was an early center of printing in Europe. This dock likely served printers who had workshops near Santa Maria Formosa, where they produced books, pamphlets, and other printed materials.
Named after the crossbowmen who practiced nearby. Venice maintained citizen militia units throughout its territories, and crossbowmen were an important part of Venice's military capabilities.
This dock would have been used by the parish priest of Santa Maria Formosa. It might have had privileged status and been reserved for ecclesiastical use.
Named for the money changers or treasurers who worked nearby. The area around Santa Maria Formosa had several banking establishments in Renaissance Venice.
This dock served artisans specialized in detailed metal engraving and chasing. These craftsmen were highly respected in Renaissance Venice for their decorative work on precious objects.
Named after the powerful Mocenigo family who had property in the area. The Mocenigos produced several doges (rulers) of Venice during the Renaissance period.
Possibly named after a crescent-shaped bend in the canal, or after a building with a moon insignia nearby. Celestial imagery was common in Venetian naming conventions.
This dock may have been near a convent or a house for unmarried women. Santa Maria Formosa area had several institutions that housed young women from noble families.
Named for the merchants who dealt in second-hand clothing and textiles. These were important tradespeople in Renaissance Venice, where fabric and clothing were valuable commodities.
This dock served the many brokers who facilitated trade in Renaissance Venice. Near Santa Maria Formosa, these intermediaries would have arranged deals between merchants and buyers.
Named after the ceremonial horn-shaped cap worn by the Doge of Venice. This might indicate a route used during official processions involving the Doge near the Santa Maria Formosa district.
This dock served the craftsmen who made and repaired swords and other bladed weapons. These artisans were essential in a maritime republic that needed to arm its ships and soldiers.

Directly related to Calle del Gran, this dock would have been used for unloading grain shipments. Food security was a major concern for Venice, and grain storage facilities were distributed throughout the city.
Named after artisans who worked with reeds and canes to make baskets, fishing equipment, and household items. These craftsmen had workshops in the Santa Maria Formosa area.

Named for the Venetian officials responsible for public finance. This dock might have been used for official business related to tax collection or treasury functions near the Santa Maria Formosa district.
This dock served the specialized textile workers who produced luxury velvet fabrics. Venice was renowned for its fine textiles during the Renaissance, with velvet being particularly valuable.
Named after a nearby charitable institution. Venice had numerous organizations dedicated to caring for orphans, the poor, and the sick, some of which were located in the Santa Maria Formosa parish.
This dock was named for the puppeteers who performed in the area. Puppet shows were popular entertainment in Renaissance Venice, often featuring at festivals and public celebrations.
This dock may have been associated with noble or knightly families living near Santa Maria Formosa, or perhaps with the Knights of Malta who had connections to Venice during the Renaissance period.

connection.historicalDescription: This bridge near Santa Maria Formosa was named after the bakery guild that operated several establishments in the area during the 15th and 16th centuries. The area was known for supplying bread to both local residents and passing merchants.

Named for its proximity to the Church of Santa Maria Formosa, one of the oldest in Venice, founded in the 7th century. The name 'Formosa' refers to the vision of the Virgin Mary as a 'beautiful' (formosa) matron that led to the church's construction.

This bridge references the grain warehouses that existed in the area during the Renaissance period. The 'Calle del Gran' in the neighborhood's name likely refers to these granaries, which were vital to Venice's food supply and commerce.

Named after the noble Grimani family who owned a palazzo near Santa Maria Formosa. The Grimani were prominent in Venetian politics, producing doges, cardinals, and naval commanders during the Renaissance, and were important patrons in this parish.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the goldsmiths who had their workshops in this area near Santa Maria Formosa. Goldsmiths were an important guild in Renaissance Venice, creating luxury items for wealthy merchants.

The term 'parangon' referred to a standard of quality or measurement used by merchants. This street near Santa Maria Formosa likely housed officials who verified weights and measures for the nearby contract.
Named after reported miraculous events or a small shrine with a revered icon that was believed to have healing powers, a common feature in Renaissance Venetian neighborhoods.
Named after the wooden trestles used by artisans or merchants to display their goods near the canal in this area of Santa Maria Formosa parish.
Named for the artillery specialists who might have lived here or for proximity to an arsenal storage facility. Venice maintained a professional artillery corps for its navy and city defenses.
A former canal that was filled in, likely named after the Biri family who were merchants in Renaissance Venice with connections to the Santa Maria Formosa area.
Possibly named after almond vendors or confectioners who specialized in almond-based sweets, which were popular luxury items in Renaissance Venice.
Named after the Consorti, a group of families who jointly funded the paving of this street with stone, making it a 'salizada' rather than an ordinary calle.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Small Square of the Bell Makers
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A small square named after craftsmen who made small bells used for shops, homes, and churches in the vicinity of Santa Maria Formosa.
Named after people from Friuli who settled in this part of Venice, forming a small community. Regional communities often lived together in specific neighborhoods of Renaissance Venice.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Foundation of the Old Malvasia Wine Shop
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after an old tavern that specialized in selling Malvasia wine, a sweet wine from Greece that was popular in Venice during the Renaissance period.
A small enclosed courtyard where blacksmiths and metal workers had their workshops, providing metal goods to the residents of Santa Maria Formosa.
A small side street named either after a notable grapevine growing there or after a family named Vida who owned property on this street.
Named after artisans who specialized in making wooden chests and caskets, important furnishings in Renaissance Venetian homes for storing valuables and textiles.
A covered passageway possibly used by a Doge (Venetian ruler) when visiting Santa Maria Formosa, or named after a property owned by a ducal family.
Named after a small garden or particularly pleasant area near Santa Maria Formosa, or possibly after a family property described as a 'small paradise'.
A former canal that was filled in during expansion works, named after properties owned by the Procurators of St. Mark, important Venetian officials who managed charitable funds.
Named after craftsmen who produced the famous Venetian mirrors, a luxury export during the Renaissance. Venice was renowned for its glassmaking techniques.
A courtyard named after Bulgarian merchants who had residences or warehouses here, reflecting Venice's status as a multicultural trading center during the Renaissance.
Named after the Coronelli family, who might have been notable mapmakers or globe makers in this area near Santa Maria Formosa.

A paved street near the Greek Orthodox community that settled around Santa Maria Formosa, representing the significant Greek presence in Renaissance Venice due to trade and migration from Byzantine territories.
Named after a former location of the Pietà orphanage and music school, which was known for taking in abandoned children and providing them with musical education.
A covered passageway used by or named after merchants trading with the Eastern Mediterranean (Levant), reflecting Venice's important commercial ties with these regions.
Named after craftsmen who specialized in making oars for Venetian boats and gondolas, an essential craft in a city built on water and dependent on maritime transportation.
A small square where stonemasons had their workshops or gathered to receive commissions for work on the many stone buildings in Venice, including those around Santa Maria Formosa.
Named after one of the Doges from the powerful Michiel family who ruled Venice during different periods of the Republic's history, possibly one who had a connection to Santa Maria Formosa.
A commercial street where Albanian merchants or craftsmen had their businesses, representing another immigrant community in multicultural Renaissance Venice.
Named after shield makers or a location where military equipment was stored, reflecting Venice's need for defensive armaments for its naval and land forces.
Named after workers who used pitch for caulking and waterproofing ships, an essential trade in Venice's maritime economy, with workshops likely located near this street.
A former canal filled to create a street, named after the noble Querini Stampalia family who had their palazzo near Santa Maria Formosa and were important patrons in Renaissance Venice.
Named after merchants who specialized in selling cotton (bombaso in Venetian dialect), which was an important imported textile material in Renaissance Venice.
A courtyard named after a business that sold sand, which was used for various purposes including construction, glass-making, and as a cleaning abrasive in Renaissance Venice.
A covered passageway named after or used by the gondoliers who operated ferry services across the canals near Santa Maria Formosa, an essential transportation service in Venice.
Named after craftsmen who made buckles and clasps for clothing and accessories, representing the specialized luxury crafts that flourished in Renaissance Venice.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Cheese Seller
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A paved street named after a prominent cheese merchant's shop or family, indicating the presence of food contracts near Santa Maria Formosa.
Named after cloth merchants who sold fine textiles, a key luxury commodity in Renaissance Venice's commercial economy.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of Our Lady of Loreto
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a shrine or small chapel dedicated to the Virgin of Loreto, showing the devotional practices in Renaissance Venice and connections to wider Italian religious traditions.
A small square where Armenian merchants or craftsmen gathered or lived, representing another of the foreign communities that contributed to Venice's multicultural character.
Named after craftsmen who prepared and sold fur garments, which were luxury items signifying wealth and status in Renaissance Venice, especially during winter.
A former canal filled to create a street, likely where herb sellers had their stalls, providing spices, medicinal herbs, and cooking ingredients to the residents near Santa Maria Formosa.
Named after crossbow makers or members of Venice's crossbow corps who may have lived or trained in this area, representing the city's military organization.
A covered passageway named after a religious confraternity based near Santa Maria Formosa, reflecting the important role these organizations played in Renaissance Venetian social and religious life.
Named after a shop sign that featured a golden head, possibly a pharmacy or apothecary which often used such distinctive signs in Renaissance Venice.
A courtyard named either for its distinctive paving using many stones or metaphorically referring to the many small businesses or workshops located there.
Named after wine sellers who had their shops along this canal-side street, importing wines from mainland Italy and Greece to satisfy Venetian tastes.
Named after the residence of the parish priest of Santa Maria Formosa, indicating the street's proximity to the parish church or rectory.
A small side street named either after bell foundries nearby or because it led toward the bell tower of Santa Maria Formosa or another nearby church.
Named after craftsmen who made armor and weapons, an important industry in a maritime republic that needed to equip its naval forces and merchant vessels for protection.
A covered passageway used by or named after the city police officers (birri) who maintained order in the Santa Maria Formosa district.
Named after craftsmen who worked with tin and other metals to create household items, reflecting the specialization of crafts in Renaissance Venice.
Named after the Borghesani family who likely paid for the paving of this street near Santa Maria Formosa, showing how wealthy families contributed to urban infrastructure.
A courtyard where candle makers had their workshops, producing essential items for home lighting and church ceremonies in Renaissance Venice.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the New Malvasia Wine Shop
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after a newer tavern that specialized in Malvasia wine, possibly established after the original Malvasia tavern in the area became successful.
Named after bakers who had their shops along this canal-side street, providing bread and baked goods to the residents of Santa Maria Formosa parish.
Named after one of the Doges from the Grimani family, likely Antonio Grimani (1521-1523) or Marino Grimani (1595-1605), who may have had connections to this area of Venice.
A small square where shoemakers had their workshops, representing one of the essential craft guilds in Renaissance Venice.
Named after storage warehouses located on this street near Santa Maria Formosa, where merchants kept their goods before distribution or sale.

buildingPoints.streetName: Rio Terà di Santa Maria Formosa
buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of Santa Maria Formosa
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A former canal near the church of Santa Maria Formosa that was filled in to create additional land for development as the parish grew in importance and population.
